Use a barter system: In the absence of paper money and coins, people would have to rely on bartering to exchange goods and services. This could involve negotiating directly with the vendor for the goods or services you want, using items of equal value to make the exchange. For example, you could trade a basket of fruits for a loaf of bread.

Use cryptocurrency: Cryptocurrencies are digital currencies that use encryption techniques to secure their transactions and to control the creation of new units. They are decentralized, meaning they are not controlled by any government or financial institution. If all paper money and coins disappeared, cryptocurrencies could become the new form of currency.

Use a mobile payment system: Mobile payment systems, such as PayPal and Apple Pay, allow you to make payments using your smartphone. If all paper money and coins disappeared, mobile payment systems could become the new way to pay for things.

Use a local exchange trading system: A local exchange trading system (LETS) is a community-based system for exchanging goods and services. It is based on the principles of mutual aid, cooperation, and sustainability. If all paper money and coins disappeared, LETS could become the new way to exchange goods and services.

Use a gift economy: A gift economy is a system in which goods and services are exchanged without the use of money. People in a gift economy rely on generosity and mutual aid to meet their needs. If all paper money and coins disappeared, a gift economy could become the new way to exchange goods and services.
